We‚Äôre excited that you‚Äôre here and want to contribute.
We want to ensure that every user and contributor feels welcome, included and supported to participate in

community.
We hope that the information provided in this document will make it as easy as possible for you to get involved.

We welcome all contributions to this project via GitHub issues and pull requests.
Please follow these guidelines to make sure your contributions can be easily integrated into the projects.

aims to be inclusive to people from all walks of life and to all research fields.
These intentions must be reflected in the contributions that we make to the project.
In addition to the CoC, we encourage intentional, inclusive actions from contributors to

.
Here are a few examples of such actions:
use respectful, gender-neutral and inclusive language (learn more about inclusive writing on page 22 of
University of Leicester Study Skills pdf
aim to include perspectives of researchers from different research backgrounds such as science, humanities and social sciences by not limiting the scope to only scientific domains.

make sure that the colour palettes are accessible to colour-blind readers and contributors.
See the blogpost
Designing Scientific Figures for Colour Blindness

for an example of how somebody improved one of their diagrams, including links to recommended colour palettes and a colour-blindness simulator. for an example of how somebody improved one of their diagrams, including links to recommended colour palettes and a colour-blindness simulator.

is a really useful tool for version control.
sits on top of Git and supports collaborative and distributed working.
We know that it can be daunting to start using Git and GitHub if you haven‚Äôt worked with them in the past, but
maintainers are here to help you figure out any of the jargon or confusing instructions you encounter! ‚ù§Ô∏è

to help you get going.

Most of the writing that you‚Äôll do will be in

.
You can think of Markdown as a few little symbols around your text that will allow GitHub to render the text with a little bit of formatting.
For example, you could write words as
Also when writing in Markdown, please
start each new sentence on a new line

.
Having each sentence on a new line will make no difference to how the text is displayed, there will still be paragraphs, but it makes the
diffs produced during the pull request
Before you open a new issue, please check if any of our

cover your idea already.
If you open a new issue, please follow our basic guidelines laid out in our

.
There are 3 issue templates to choose from.:
):  This issue is a place to discuss matters relating to writing a new chapter on a new topic or adding a subchapter in an already existing chapter.
):  Use this template for a general issue related to the book, community, process or ideas.
The list of labels for current issues can be found
When a bug or minor changes have been made, contributors can label their PR along with ‚Äúbug fixed‚Äù.
These issues relate to documentation and resources around building a BinderHub.
These issues are related to the build of the book using Jupyter-book. They are also related to the-turing-way book repo.
These issues are reporting a problem or a mistake in the project.

The more details you can provide the better!
If you know how to fix the bug, please open an issue first and then submit a pull request :sparkles:
These are bugs that have been fixed and only need approval.
These issues relate to the content of the collaboration book.
These issues discuss how we as a project interact with other initiatives.
These issues relate to the content of the communication book.
These issues relate to building and supporting the Turing Way community.
This is all about collaborating, so please let us know how we can best support you as a community member.
These issues mark issues and pull requests with conflicting files and errors.
These issues relate to pull requests that update a dependency file.
These issues are suggesting new features that can be added to the project.
If you want to ask for something new, please try to make sure that your request is distinct from any others that are already in the queue (or part of

).
If you find one that‚Äôs similar but there are subtle differences please reference the other enhancement in your issue.
These issues relate to the content of the ethics book.
These issues relate to coordinating workshops, book dashes and any other events.
These issues are particularly appropriate if it is your first contribution to

If you‚Äôre not sure about how to go about contributing, these are good places to start. You‚Äôll be mentored through the process by the maintainers team.
If you‚Äôre a seasoned contributor, please select a different issue to work from and keep these available for the newer and potentially more anxious team members.
These issues contain a task that a member of the team has determined we need additional help with.
If you feel that you can contribute to one of these issues, we especially encourage you to do so!
These issues can be used for inviting discussion from collaborators or community in general.
These issues contain items that can be added to the newsletter.
These issues relate to topics to reach out to the community.
These pull requests are for the new members of
community who want to start with reviewing and approving some simple pull requests.
If you are a new member of

and are looking for opportunities to start as a reviewer of contributions made on our Github repository, these pull requests are a great starting point for you. Issues like small modifications, typo errors and minor bug fixes are resolved by these PRs which are easy to review as a beginner.
These issues relate to draft pull requests.
These issues relate to pull requests that have been merged.
These issues relate to pulling requests that have been partially approved.
These issues relate to pull requests that have been approved by a reviewer.
These issues relate to pull requests for which a reviewer has requested changes.
These issues relate to pull requests that have not been reviewed yet.
These issues relate to the content of the project design book.
We like to model best practice, so

itself is managed through these issues.
These issues help us to coordinate some logistics.
These issues contain a question that you‚Äôd like to have answered.
lots of ways to ask questions
but opening an issue is a great way to start a conversation and get your answer.
These issues can be used after approving a pull request to let the author know that they can merge it.
These issues relate to the content of the reproducibility book.
These issues relate to the theoretical side of research best practices.
These relate to pull requests for urgent review requests, for example, to approve a report, abstract, and newsletter.
These relate to issues and pull requests that may need some software development, design, or troubleshooting skills.
These issues discuss the tools we use for collaboration
If you feel that we should try new tools or that some aspects of the collaboration could be improved by using tools, please let us know.
These issues relate to translating the reproducibility book into other languages.
These issues relate to fixing typos and broken links.
These issues are work in progress.

The following steps are a guide to help you contribute in a way that will be easy for everyone to review and accept with ease :sunglasses:.

Remember, if you open a new issue, please follow our basic guidelines laid out in our

.
The issue template will automatically be rendered in the comment section of the new issue page so all you need to do is edit the ‚Äú
This is now your own unique copy of

.
Changes here won‚Äôt affect anyone else‚Äôs work, so it‚Äôs a safe space to explore edits to the code!
keep your fork up to date
with the main repository, otherwise, you can end up with lots of dreaded

.
If you prefer working in the browser,
describe how to sync your fork to the original repository via GitHub.

Try to keep the changes focused.
If you submit a large amount of work all in one go it will be much more work for whoever is reviewing your pull request.
While making your changes, commit often and write good, detailed commit messages.

explains how to write a good Git commit message and why it matters.
It is also perfectly fine to have a lot of commits - including ones that break code.
A good rule of thumb is to push up to GitHub when you
have passing tests then the continuous integration (CI) has a good chance of passing everything. üò∏
If you feel tempted to ‚Äúbranch out‚Äù then please make a
details the different Git branching models.

Please do not re-write history!
That is, please do not use the
command to edit previous commit messages, combine multiple commits into one, or delete or revert commits that are no longer necessary.
Are you new to Git and GitHub or just want a detailed guide on getting started with version control? Check out our

We encourage you to open a pull request as early in your contributing process as possible.
This allows everyone to see what is currently being worked on.
It also provides you, the contributor, feedback in real-time from both the community and the continuous integration as you make commits (which will help prevent stuff from breaking).
When you are ready to submit a pull request, you will automatically see the

contents in the pull request body.
It asks you to:
Describe the problem you‚Äôre trying to fix in the pull request, reference any related issue and use fixes/close to automatically close them, if pertinent.
List of changes proposed in the pull request.
Describe what the reviewer should concentrate their feedback on.
‚Äù sections of the pull request template with as much detail as possible, you will make it really easy for someone to review your contribution!

If you have opened the pull request early and know that its contents are not ready for review or to be merged, add ‚Äú[WIP]‚Äù at the start of the pull request title, which stands for ‚ÄúWork in Progress‚Äù.
When you are happy with it and are happy for it to be merged into the main repository, change the ‚Äú[WIP]‚Äù in the title of the pull request to ‚Äú[Ready for review]‚Äù.

team will then review your changes to confirm that they can be merged into the main repository.
A

will probably consist of a few questions to help clarify the work you‚Äôve done.
Keep an eye on your GitHub notifications and be prepared to join in that conversation.

and the pull request will automatically update with those changes.
You don‚Äôt need to submit a new pull request when you make a change in response to a review.

You can also submit pull requests to other contributors‚Äô branches!
Do you see an

that you find interesting and want to contribute to?
Simply make your edits on their files and open a pull request to their branch!

What happens if the continuous integration (CI) fails (for example, if the pull request notifies you that ‚ÄúSome checks were not successful‚Äù)?
The CI could fail for a number of reasons.
At the bottom of the pull request, where it says whether your build passed or failed, you can click ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù next to the test, which takes you to a CI run log site.
If you have the write access to the repo, you can view the log or rerun the checks by clicking the ‚ÄúRestart build‚Äù button in the top right.
You can learn more about CI in the
to the pull request workflow, but please
if you have not done so already.
On your fork create a branch with the name as the chapter to be written and create a markdown file on it.
If you are a contributor to the project repository, you can also create a branch on the main repository with the same name as the chapter to be written without creating a fork (or a local copy).
Copy the relevant part of the
into the markdown file, and commit.

version of the chapter branch.
The title of this request should have the form ‚Äú[WIP] Write Chapter_name chapter‚Äù.
WIP indicates the chapter is a Work In Progress and not yet ready for review.

On your branch add material to the chapter and commit.
The goal of this project is to collate and build on the many good resources already available about good practice in data science.
As such this material should primarily be drawn from outside sources.
Note the link and (if available) license of the source.
Once a significant amount of material has been amassed, work (preferably with others) to develop a chapter outline.
Edit the amassed material into a coherent chapter, adding more material if gaps become apparent.
Once the first draft of the chapter is complete change [WIP] in the pull request title to [Ready for review].

Add a comment on the pull request indicating that this chapter is ready for high-level review, i.e discussion of changes of the scale of a paragraph or larger such as adding material and restructuring sections.
Discuss and make these high-level changes on this pull request. Once this is complete merge the chapter into The
Make another pull request from your fork‚Äôs version of the branch to
‚Äôs version of the branch. Title this ‚Äú[Ready for review] Chapter_name chapter- low-level reviews‚Äù.
Discuss and make low-level changes to the chapter on this pull request, such as rewording sentences, typos and the like.
This division of the pull requests into high and low-level changes stops discussion threads from becoming unmanageable.
Once this is complete merge the pull request into
‚Äôs version of the chapter branch into

(Don‚Äôt feel bad, we have all done it! üôà)
Simply close the pull request and delete the branch (

).

or by opening an issue, and
